entry.title: Imagine Science
entry.content:

Years active: January 2018-present.

Home

Media

Imagine Science Abu Dhabi Official Website

Imagine Science on Facebook

Imagine Science on Twitter

Imagine Science on Instagram

Imagine Science on YouTube

Imagine Science on Vimeo

Imagine Science on Google Plus

NYUAD Library

This guide was created by Amani Magid, Science and Engineering Librarian, from the NYUAD Library.  If you have any questions or suggestions, please contact us at nyuad.library@nyu.edu. 

About Imagine Science Film Festival Abu Dhabi

Imagine Science Film Festival Abu Dhabi is a film and sci-art festival with a focus on science/engineering. The Abu Dhabi festival is now in its second season at New York University Abu Dhabi. The festival consists of short and feature film screenings, along with panel discussions, Q&As, talks, workshops and performances on science subjects and subjects inspired from science. All festival activities are free of charge.

Film Festival: February 18-20

Art Exhibition: February 18-23

Imagine Science Film Festival began more than eight years ago in New York City and was founded by Alexis Gambis, who is the executive director and also an Assistant Professor of Biology, Film and New Media. Alexis saw that there was a dearth of films about science and felt that film would be a great avenue for presenting science concepts to the public. Therefore, after obtaining doctorate and masters's degrees in the sciences, he obtained an MFA in film from NYU. Since then he has been actively producing films on science and founded Imagine Science Film Festival so that he and other filmmakers can have a platform for presenting science-themed films to the public.

 

NYUAD Arts Center

THE ARTS CENTER

music + theater + dance + film + spoken

word+ multi-media + conversation + culture

under one roof

Student Film Lab

About

SOURCE

The Student Film Lab is the outreach of Imagine Science Film Festival. Students from high schools in Abu Dhabi are recruited to take part in a lab in which they create their own film. The students are given a couple of weeks to film their footage and they are then given a quick course in film editing. According to Imagine Science "Our goal is to help students create a window into the world of a science lab, enabling them to appreciate science through the filmmaking process and then to share the results with others".

This year's theme is "Air above us, air around us".

Events

STUDENT FILM LAB LAUNCH-JANUARY 25

Students record video using their mobile devices.

WORKSHOP-FEBRUARY 2 & 4, NYUAD Institute

Students spend the morning listening to different aspects of filmmaking from guest lectures. In the afternoon, students are taught how to edit their videos from NYUAD Film Instructors.

SCREENING-FEBRUARY 17: 3pm-5pm, NYUAD Arts Center Black Box Theatre

All films created at the Student Film Lab will be shown

EXHIBIT-FEBRUARY 18-23

February 18-20 12:00PM-10:00PM

February 21-23  12:00PM-8:00PM

All student films and other films will be shown on loop in the exhibit

 

 

STEM VS STEAM INFOGRAPHIC

SOURCE

 

Organizations incorporating arts into STEM Education

  • STEM to STEAM
    Founded by the Rhode Island School of Design, this organization ecourages incorporating art and design to help students learn about science, technology, engineering and mathematics.
  • STEAM not STEM
    Our mission is to have business leaders, arts professionals, educators and others work together to educate governments, the public and the media to the need for returning Arts to the national curricula.
  • Edutopia-STEM to STEAM: Resources Toolkit
    Whether you are looking for resources on integrating science, technology, engineering, and math or on infusing the arts to transform STEM into STEAM, these curated compilations will help you plan different approaches to integrated studies.

LIterature on use of film for teaching STEM students

  • (Re)Counting Meaningful Learning Experiences: Using Student-Created Reflective Videos to Make Invisible Learning Visible During PjBL Experiences by Smith, Shaunna
    Publication Date: Apr 2016
    This ethnographic case study investigated how the process of learning during a yearlong after-school, project-based learning (PjBL) experience could be documented by student-created reflective videos. Guided by social constructivism, constant comparative analysis was used to explore the meaningful learning that took place in addition to the planned curricula, resulting in an exploration of the intersections of life lessons that include (a) "making learning more real," (b) being "on a mission to change the world," and (c) "you can't control anybody but yourself." Findings from the study indicate that student-created reflective videos can document meaningful learning that is capable of "counting" both as a creative form of self-expression and an alternative form of measuring the learning process throughout PjBL. [ABSTRACT FROM AUTHOR]
  • Motion picture science: A fully integrated fine Arts/STEM degree program. by Scholl, Victoria M. Iafrati, Megan M. Long, David L. Pow, Joseph J.
    Publication Date: 2014 2014 IEEE Integrated STEM Education Conference

Sci-Art Exhibition

Atmospheres

Atmosphere is an exhibit that looks at the crossroads of science and art. It features gallery talks, film showings, and more! This year's exhibit is centered around the theme of Atmospheres in both a literal and metaphonic sense.

http://www.nyuad-artscenter.org/en_US/events/2016/sci-art-exhibition/

Learn about Science in Film

Featured Database

 

A comprehensive index covering the entire spectrum of television and film writing and produced for a broad target audience, from film scholars to general viewers. Subject coverage includes: film & television theory, preservation & restoration, writing, production, cinematography, technical aspects, and reviews. Dates of coverage: 1914 to present.

Go to this Database!

Google Scholar Search

Use Google Scholar to find out what's been written about your topic:

Relevant themes and keywords

Intrigued by Imagine Science Film Festival and want to find out more?  You may find the following keywords helpful as you search NYU's music databases listed below:

  • Science AND film NOT fiction
  • STEM education AND film
  • Science AND documentary

Find more in these databases

  • EBSCO Discovery Service
    EBSCO Discovery Service (EDS) encompasses articles in databases across many disciplines. Users can locate peer reviewed articles, videos, audio files, images, and more from a range of subjects.
  • Arts and Humanities Citation Index (A&HCI)
    This database indexes about 1,700 arts and humanities journals. Dates of coverage: 1975 to present.
    Adjust settings to expand your searching to include the Social Sciences Citation Index, the Science Citation Index, the Book Citation Index, and others.
  • Film Literature Index
    Indexes 150 film and television periodicals from 30 countries cover-to-cover and 200 other periodicals selectively for articles on film and television. The periodicals range from the scholarly to the popular. Contains approximately 700,000 citations to articles, film reviews and book reviews published between 1976-2001.
  • Scopus
    Find articles in the sciences and use the citation index to discover citations of relevant articles.
  • Web of Science
    Search for articles in the sciences and the articles that cite them.

Films on science in the Library

Here are a sampling of films available at the NYUAD Library. To look at all of our films use the following search terms: "Science film NOT fiction". Under "Limit to" click on Video.

  • The Harriman Alaska Expedition retraced
    Call Number: DVDAD 4539
    Two scientific expeditions to Alaska, 100 years apart, give an unparalleled view of environmental damage and the change in society's attitudes.
  • The wisdom to survive : climate change, capitalism & community
    Call Number: DVDAD 4458
    "The wisdom to survive accepts the consensus of scientists that climate change has already arrived, and asks, what is keeping us from action? The film explores how unlimited growth and greed are destroying the life support system of the planet, the social fabric of society, and the lives of billions of people. Will we have the wisdom to survive? The film features thought leaders and activists in the realms of science, economics and spirituality discussing how we can evolve and take action in the face of climate disruption. They urge us to open ourselves to the beauty that surrounds us and get to work on ensuring it thrives. Among those featured are Bill McKibben, Joanna Macy, Nikki Cooley, Roger Payne, Richard Heinberg, Amy Seidl, Stephanie Kaza, Gus Speth, Jihan Gearan, and Ben Falk"
  • Dirty paradise
    Call Number: DVDAD 4837 P
    Today an incredible sanitary and ecological disaster is taking place in the heart of the Amazonia in an overseas department of France, on the border between Suriman and French Guyana. ´Dirty Paradiseª shares the story of a thousand Indians who are trying to survive the devastation caused by 10,000 illegal gold-seekers who hide in the forests.
  • Natural State. Episode 26
    Call Number: Available online
    Pollution Measuring - A facility in Leicester examining levels of pollution around the world. Renewable Energy Forum - A two day forum looking at alternative energy sources available to consumers. Drinking Straw - A look at a new straw that acts as a filter and makes any water anywhere instantly drinkable. Ocean Science Study - A research centre to study all components of ocean science. Ballooning - A look at the benefits of this eco-friendly tourist attraction. Solar Car Improvements - Here we look at the new developments for the British car in the Trans Australia Solar Race. Cambodia Bio-gas - An alternative cooking method in this impoverished country. India Solar Power - Remote villagers are finding enormous benefits from this new source of power. Antarctic Dry Valley - Scientists are studying volcanic activity in this harsh environment. UK Coral - Here we look at a unique eco - system off the coast of England containing a rare breed of coral.
  • Earth : the power of the planet
    Call Number: DVDAD 670
    Travelling from Ethiopia's unique lava lake to an ice cave under a glacier in Greenland and a host of amazing locations in between, we examine the forces that have helped create and foster life on Earth - from the volcanic eruptions that shaped the land to the development of the unique formula of the air that we breathe.
  • Through the looking glass : the mirror and the self-conscious
    Call Number: DVDAD 4658
    When do humans develop self-consciousness and recognition of others as separate beings? Do these psychological advancements occur differently in animals? Many scientists think so, using the most advanced of scientific equipment to base their conclusions: the common mirror. This engaging and sometimes surprising documentary builds a case for the mirror's role in determining the stages of psychological progress in humans and animals. Field experiments conducted by Jim Anderson, researcher in psychology at Sterling University in Scotland, illustrate how the mirror's secrets teach much about the intelligence of the animal world.
  • The linguists
    Call Number: DVDAD 4720 1 teacher's guide
    Joins David Harrison and Gregory Anderson, scientists racing to document languages on the verge of extinction. In Siberia, India and Bolivia, David and Greg's resolve is tested by the very forces stifling languages: institutionalized racism and violent economic unrest. The scientists must overcome their own fears and preconceived notions to draw speakers from decades of silence. Their journey takes them deep into the heart of the cultures, knowledge, and communities at stake.
  • The Race for the double helix
    Call Number: DVDAD 3424
    Set in the years 1951-1953 and told from the point of view of the young scientist James "Jim" Watson, this film portrays the discovery of the double helix comprising human genetic material. According to the film, the discovery was primarily made by woman scientist Rosalind Franklin, but her ideas were stolen by the team of Watson, Crick and Wilkins who were subsequently awarded the Nobel Prize.

Recent News Coverage

Find more

  • Nexis Uni
    Nexis Uni ​(Formerly LexisNexis Academic Universe) provides access to full-text newspapers (U.S. and some international), news wires, transcripts, and trade journals.
    Please clear your browser's cache and cookies before attempting to access this resource.
  • Google News

Imagine Science videos

In the News

  • Imagine Science Abu Dhabi Festival at NYU Abu Dhabi announces 2016 program
  • Science and cinema to meet in Abu Dhabi film festival
    The National aricle
  • Abu Dhabi festival to explore eco balance
    Gulf Today article
  • 1st science film festival in Abu Dhabi on February 19th
    Ministry of Higher Education & Scientific Research

More events at The NYUAD Arts Center

http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/news-events/arts-center.html

More events at NYUAD

http://nyuad.nyu.edu/en/news-events/abu-dhabi-events.html

NYUAD Library

NYUAD Library

The library facility provides spaces for engagement between faculty and students, complemented by quiet areas for concentration and contemplation. Service to scholars is the primary mission of the NYUAD library staff. Value is placed on saving time for researchers, providing requested items efficiently, informing scholars of new resources and offering assistance in finding, using, analyzing, and presenting knowledge.

The NYUAD Library offers a growing print collection and access to myriad electronic resources via NYU New York:

  • 90,000 journal titles
  • 1,000+ databases
  • Nearly a million e-books, audio, and video files

These electronic resources are accessible within the library and remotely. NYUAD users can also request books from NYU New York's 3.9-million-title collection.

Comfortable reading areas and small and large group study rooms create a productive atmosphere for research. The dedicated silent study area on the Mezzanine level provides plenty of space for students to focus on their research in a relaxed environment.

Reference and research assistance is currently available via telephone, email, chat, and in-person at our Information Desk.

Information for Visitors

The NYUAD Library is primarily intended for use by our faculty, students, and staff. Members of the Abu Dhabi community may be granted library privileges through the Visiting Scholar program. If you have a special research need that requires the use of our library, please apply for this program using the Visiting Scholar Application (PDF).

Media

  • Facebook
    Follow us on Facebook.
  • Twitter
    Follow us on Twitter.
  • Instagram
    Follow us on Instagram.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

entry.title: NYUADGIS
entry.content:
About

Creator: Taylor Hixson

Usage: This guide was used to support geospatial teaching and research across campus. The guide includes resources for course integrated support, such as workshop materials and written tutorials.

Years active: January 2018-present.

Return to Old Guides Online

GIS Home - Geographic Information Systems - Research Guides at New York University
  1. NYU Libraries
  2. Research Guides
  3. Abu Dhabi Library
  4. Geographic Information Systems
  5. GIS Home

Geographic Information Systems: GIS Home

Geographic information systems and spatial data resources for the NYU Abu Dhabi community.
  • GIS Home
  • Spatial Data Resources
  • Learn GIS
  • Instruction Toggle Dropdown
    • Boundaries: CSTS-UH 1021EQ
    • DHS: CDAD-UH-1033Q
    • Geospatial Guidance
    • WIDH: Spatial Humanities
    • ASCE SIG
  • <a title="" class="" href="javascript:void(0);" style="font-style:italic;"onclick="jQuery('html, body').animate({ scrollTop: jQuery('#s-lg-page-section-6686905').offset().top }, 750);" aria-label="Faculty Consulting" > Faculty Consulting </a>

GIS Home

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYUAD GIS workshops

Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are any set of tools or technologies used to collect, integrate, store, edit, analyze, share, or display geographic information. GIS applications are tools that allow users to create interactive queries, analyze spatial information, edit data in maps, and present the results of all these operations.

Access GIS at NYUAD

Access Desktop GIS

  • GIS in the Center for Digital Scholarship
    NYUAD Library's Center for Digital Scholarships has two PCs with increased RAM and storage for students, faculty, and researchers to use for geospatial projects. The computers include the following software for geospatial projects:
      ArcGIS, including ArcGIS Pro
      QGIS
      GRASS GIS
      SketchUp
      GeoDa
      R/R Studio
      Python (IDLE)
      Google Earth Pro
  • Access QGIS at NYUAD Library
    QGIS is available in the library's instructional classroom (303) and the advanced media center (306). QGIS is a free and open-source software compatible with Mac, PC, and Linux
  • Access ArcGIS at NYUAD
    ArcGIS is available on all public PCs in the library. Scroll to ArcGIS in this spreadsheet to find all the places elsewhere on campus where ArcGIS is installed.
  • Access ArcGIS Pro at NYUAD Library
    ArcGIS Pro is available on the two GIS PCs in the Library's Center for Digital Scholarship. If requested, the Center for Academic Technology can provide ArcGIS Pro with any install of ArcGIS. ArcGIS Pro requires users to have an ArcGIS Online account. Email NYUAD librarian for geospatial data services or NYU Data Services for an NYU account.
  • Request an ArcGIS license
    The Center for Academic Technology provides free ArcGIS licenses to students, faculty, and researchers. E-mail nyuad.academictech@nyu.edu for a license. Students should include in the email their first and last name, netID, major (area of study), and operating system for all software requests.

Access Web GIS

  • ArcGIS Online, Story Maps & Survey123
    For access to the NYU ArcGIS Online organizational account--which includes Story Maps, Survey123 and Esri training--e-mail taylor.hixson@nyu.edu or data.services@nyu.edu to set up your account.
  • Access Carto at NYUAD
    Use your NYU email to create a free account.

Consulting Guidelines

Services provided

  • Our role is to facilitate your geospatial analysis within the realm of our supported software packages (i.e., ArcGIS, QGIS, Carto, ArcGIS Online, and Esri Story Maps). We can assist you with issues that you may encounter with respect to data finding (locating geospatial data), preparation (importing, merging, and cleaning data), analysis (geoprocessing), and results (understanding the formatting of the output). We can also help you select the best package for your task, interpret error messages, and locate documentation and further resources.

  • In addition to providing regularly scheduled software-specific tutorials, we can also help instructors by providing classroom presentations to introduce geospatial software.

  • Our role is to assist you with your analysis, rather than to conduct analyses for you. It is the researcher's responsibility to ensure that the research design, analysis, and programming are justified and appropriate for the discipline at hand.

Whom we can help

Consulting services are limited to current NYU students, faculty, and staff.

Types of assistance not covered by our service

  • One-on-one GIS/mapping tutoring and general inquiries about methodology and statistical topics

  • Assistance with projects of commercial nature or those involving classified information, non-disclosure agreements, related to or likely to be involved in litigation, etc.


Original work in this LibGuide is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Spatial Data Resources

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYU Spatial Data Repository

  • Spatial Data Repository
    The best starting place for finding geospatial data owned by NYU, created by NYU faculty and students, freely available online, and resources available from other universities.

Global Open Spatial Data

  • Natural Earth Data
    Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data, with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software.
  • Global Administrative Areas
    Download individual country administrative boundaries in multiple formats.
  • IPUMS International GIS
    IPUMS provides geographic information to facilitate cross-temporal and cross-national comparative analyses. Multiple census years are available for most countries in the database. Create a free account for best user experience. NOTE: Shapefiles distributed by IPUMS-International provide generalized boundaries and are not intended for precise geographical calculations.
  • Geofabrik
    Download OpenStreetMap data, including global places of interest and street networks. Updated regularly.
  • DIVA-GIS
    Free population, infrastructure, and land data by country.
  • Humanitarian Data Exchange
    Authoritative data resources, including spatial, from global humanitarian agencies and governments.
  • Global Land Cover Facility
    The GLCF is a center for land cover science with a focus on research using remotely sensed satellite data and products to access land cover change for local to global systems.
  • NASA Earth Data
    This application allows you to search, discover, visualize, refine, and access NASA Earth Observation data. Create a free account for best user experience.
  • Google Earth Engine Explorer
    Locate and download raster data from around the world. Best for when you need a small area rather than global scale. Allows basic analysis in the workspace before downloading. Create a free account for best user experience.
  • Global Forest Watch
    Find and download geospatial data related to global forest conservation and protection, including data about local and indigenous people, biodiversity, and potential natural and human threats to forests.
  • Geolode
    A catalog of websites that offer geospatial data.
  • Open Addresses
    An essential tool for free geocoding. Regional interest includes partial coverage in Dubai, Doha, and Kuwait.

NYU Spatial Data Resources and Databases

Helpful Tools

  • Epsg.io
    A database of coordinates systems used in maps worldwide.
  • Projection Wizard
    Projection Wizard is a web application that helps cartographers select an appropriate projection for their map.
  • Map Warper
    Georeference maps online. Can export any uploaded image type as GeoTIFF, KML, and even WMS or Tile layer to use in ArcGIS Online. Note: this resource should only be used for out of U.S. copyright maps and not for proprietary or NYU access only resources as it makes all contributions publicly available.
  • geojson.io
    This website allows users to import and convert a geoJSON to a number of downloadable spatial data types, including shapefile, kml, and csv, and vice versa. Additionally, draw custom shapes in the interface and export it in multiple geospatial file formats, including shapefile, geoJSON, csv, KML, and more.
  • GeoNames
    A free database that provides a latitude and longitude for more than 11 million places worldwide. An essential tool for geocoding and finding accurate placenames.
  • Color Brewer
    A helpful tool for choosing user-friendly map colors.
  • MapChart.net
    Need a simple map visual? Make one in minutes with Map Chart!
  • Map in seconds
    Have a spreadsheet with place names that you want to turn into a choropleth map? Paste your data into this website for a map in literally seconds! 600 city, regional, and country maps are available.

Original work in this LibGuide is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Learn GIS

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

Online Learning Resources

  • LinkedIn Learning GIS Playlist
    This playlist features LinkedIn Learning (previously Lynda.com) courses for learning GIS from the ground up, including courses about finding and using public data to getting started with a desktop GIS to making maps in Illustrator.
  • Esri Virtual Campus Courses
    Learn to use ArcGIS or ArcGIS Online products with Esri Virtual Campus Courses. The courses include anything from in-depth introductory tutorials to 5-minute briefs on performing a task.
    Email taylor.hixson@nyu.edu or data.services@nyu.edu for access to the web course catalog.
  • List of GIS Moocs
    Massive open online courses, or moocs, are courses available online instructed by academics or leaders in the field. Some moocs require payment or advanced registration but are often free.
  • QGIS User-Made Tutorials
  • Geospatial Data Abstraction Library (GDAL)
    The most approachable tutorial online for getting started with GDAL! This links to part one of a four part series. Note: if following this series using a PC, use " (double quotes) anywhere ' (single quotes) are used.
  • NYU NY learning resources
    Resources for regularly offered NYU NY Data Services' GIS workshops.

NYUAD workshop resources

The NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services offers a variety of drop-in workshops throughout the academic year. Resources from some of those workshops are available below. Visit the NYUAD Library event calendar to see all library workshops offered.

  • Creating a Spatial CV
  • Georeferencing with ArcMap (2019)
  • Georeferencing with MapWarper.net
  • Geospatial Project Management: Planning document
  • Let's Make a Map: ArcGIS (2018)
  • Let's Make a Map: QGIS (2018)
  • Places to Points: Geocoding with free tools
  • Python for ArcGIS (2019)

NYUAD GIS workshops


Original work in this LibGuide is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Instruction

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYUAD GIS workshops

Class support for geospatial tools and concepts

The NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services regularly collaborates with faculty across the disciplines to offer integrated support for GIS learning. Such instruction often involves:

  • teaching or co-teaching customized in-class workshops for supported geospatial software, skills, or resources
  • working with instructors and professors to develop learner-centered assignments
  • consulting with students in small groups or one-on-one about using and finding geospatial resources for assignments
  • providing custom research guides and resources to support NYUAD courses

If you are interested in integrated course support for GIS, please reach out to the NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services for further questions or requests.

Cutomized group instruction

Any NYUAD community member may request a custom geospatial data or GIS workshop for NYUAD supported tools and services.

A minimum of three participants are required for a custom workshop. Email the NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services to further discuss workshop options and make arrangements. 

NYUAD workshop resources

The NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services offers a variety of drop-in workshops throughout the academic year. Resources from some of those workshops are available below. Visit the NYUAD Library event calendar to see all library workshops offered.

  • Creating a Spatial CV
  • Georeferencing with ArcMap (2019)
  • Georeferencing with MapWarper.net
  • Geospatial Project Management: Planning document
  • Let's Make a Map: ArcGIS (2018)
  • Let's Make a Map: QGIS (2018)
  • Places to Points: Geocoding with free tools
  • Python for ArcGIS (2019)

Boundaries: CSTS-UH 1021EQ

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYUAD GIS workshops

ArcGIS workshop resources

  • General resources
  • Days 1 & 2
  • Days 3 & 4
  • Days 5 & 6

Download workshop data

Download workshop data

Instructions

Below are links to step-by-step written instructions that will help you complete many requirements in your assignments. For example, georeferenceing, reprojecting data, and creating and editing shapefiles.

  • Instructions: Reprojecting a vector layer (shapefile)
  • Instructions: Create custom control points for georeferencing
  • Instructions: Georeferencing with ArcMap
    Review georeferencing or learn some bonus tricks not covered in class to georeference in ArcMap, including creating custom anchor points.
  • Instructions: Using MapWarper.net to georeference
    Having trouble georeferencing with ArcMap? Try the online tool MapWarper. Note: This only georeferences maps as Web Mercator (WGS 1984). Use the Project Raster tool in ArcMap to reproject as needed.
  • Instructions: Creating new shapefiles
  • Instructions: Aligning shapefile edges
    Do your shapefile borders and edges have gaps and overlaps? Follow these instructions to create cleaner, neater, more accurate shapefiles.

General resources

Below are resources used in class and suggested websites and videos for general assistance with the workshop content and course assignments.

  • Boundaries course slides, Fall 2019
  • What is ArcMap?
  • Essential ArcMap vocabulary
  • LinkedIn Learning GIS Playlist
    This playlist features LinkedIn Learning (previously Lynda.com) courses for learning GIS from the ground up, including courses about finding and using public data to getting started with a desktop GIS to making maps in Illustrator.
  • Guidelines for Creating Historical Geospatial Boundary Data
    A Story Map by Tsering Wangyal Shawa that demonstrates the process and thinking around extracting historical feature data. Includes tips on image processing, georeferencing, and aligning the historical boundaries with present day ones.
  • Eric Compas GIS YouTube
    Instructional videos that demonstrate many common and useful ArcMap tasks and tools

Common types of geospatial data: vector, raster, and tabular

  • Vector
  • Raster
  • Tabular

Common file extensions in ArcGIS

  • Common file extensions in ArcGIS
  • What is a shapefile? (.shp)
  • What is a file geodatabase? (.gdb)
  • Opening a map document (.mxd)

Georeferencing

  • Fundamentals of georeferencing
  • Georeferencing toolbar
  • Georeference by entering specific x,y coordinates (When using this method, make sure to enter six digits past the decimal point, even if all six are zeroes, e.g., 90.000000)
  • Georeference a raster to a vector
  • Written tutorial with data: Geospatial historian georeferencing lesson
  • Video tutorial with data: LinkedIn Learning training video with data (see section 11)
  • MapWarper.net is an easy to use website for georeferencing and converting any image type to a fully georeferenced GeoTIFF usable in your projects. Consult the geospatial services librarian before deciding if this is the best georeferencing option for you.

Five steps for georeferencing maps:

  1. Figure out the projection. If it is not written on the map, try finding it with epsg.io or projection wizard.
  2. Find 6 or more points on the map that would be present in a modern day map (buildings, landmarks, rail stations, points of latitude and longitude)
  3. Download shapefile(s) that match the present-day areas or places of interest in the map. For example, download countries from gadm.org, naturalearthdata.com, or create your own control points.
  4. In ArcMap, specify the coordinate system used in the original map and/or reproject the shapefile(s) to match the projection used in the map.
  5. Follow the steps for georeferencing a raster to a vector.
  • Use this starter method in conjunction with other methods of georeferencing. For example, georeferencing to an Esri basemap or known x,y values on the map. However, always make sure to specify the correct coordinate system to reduce warping and improve accuracy of future analysis.

Spatial data resources

  • Spatial Data Repository
    NYU's source for geospatial data such as vector data (shapefiles) and raster data, which includes scanned maps. This resource also shows maps and data available to download from partner institutions.
  • Global Administrative Areas
    Download individual country administrative boundaries in multiple formats.
  • Natural Earth Data
    Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data, with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software.
  • IPUMS
    IPUMS provides census and survey data, including geospatial data, from around the world integrated across time and space. IPUMS integration and documentation makes it easy to study change, conduct comparative research, merge information across data types, and analyze individuals within family and community contexts.
  • DIVA-GIS
    Free population, infrastructure, and land data by country.

Scanned maps

Below are some resources that provided historical maps and atlases.

  • Border and Migration Studies Online
    Library database that includes maps and other documentation related to the creation of borders.
  • Qatar Digital Library
    Search for and download high-quality regional maps
  • David Rumsey Map Collection
  • Perry-Castañeda Library Map Collection
    Unique maps from around the world available for free download, typically as a .jpg.
  • Old Maps Online
  • Ebook Central
    Search for "atlas" and an area of interest to find atlases with unique maps for course assignments

Library workshop resources

    Document containing written tutorial for the 10 September 2019 workshop.
  • Introduction to Story Maps slides

Further resources

  • General resources
  • ArcGIS Online & Story Maps
  • Georeferencing
  • Digitizing Maps
  • Esri/ArcGIS training catalog
    Sign in with your NYU ArcGIS Online account to access the training course catalog. Search for courses related to software used in this course such as ArcGIS Online, ArcMap, Survey123, and StoryMaps
  • LinkedIn Learning GIS Playlist
    This playlist features LinkedIn Learning (previously Lynda.com) courses for learning GIS from the ground up, including courses about finding and using public data to getting started with a desktop GIS to making maps in Illustrator.
  • Eric Compas GIS YouTube
    Instructional videos that demonstrate many common and useful ArcMap tasks and tools
  • Guidelines for Creating Historical Geospatial Boundary Data
    A Story Map by Tsering Wangyal Shawa that demonstrates the process and thinking around extracting historical feature data. Includes tips on image processing, georeferencing, and aligning the historical boundaries with present day ones.

Access

  • Both ArcGIS Online and ArcGIS Story Maps are accessible from nyuds.maps.arcgis.com.
  • Access Story Maps directly from storymaps.arcgis.com
  • If you do not have access to your NYU ArcGIS Online account, contact NYUAD librarian for geospatial data services or NYU Data Services
  • Content in NYUDS ArcGIS Online accounts may be deleted upon graduation. Contact the NYUAD librarian for geospatial data services or NYU Data Services for information about migrating content.

ArcGIS Online

  • Esri ArcGIS Online documentation
  • Esri ArcGIS Online written tutorial
  • LinkedIn Learning course: GIS on the web

Story Maps

  • Classic Story Maps Templates
    Browse and find tutorials for the classic Story Maps templates, such as Swipe, Tour, and Journal. Note: these classic templates will be retired from use in mid-2020.
  • Story Maps Frequently Asked Questions
  • Creating a Story Map tutorial
    This Story Map guides you through the different aspects and options available when creating a Story Map.
  • Instructions: Using MapWarper.net to georeference

Five steps for georeferencing in desktop GIS:

  1. Figure out the map's projection, or coordinate system (see coordinate system resources below). If the coordinate system is not written on the map, try finding it with epsg.io or projection wizard.
  2. Find 6 or more points on the map that would be present in a modern day map (buildings, landmarks, rail stations, points of latitude and longitude)
  3. Download shapefile(s) from gadm.org that match the present-day country or countries in the map.
  4. In the GIS, specify the coordinate system and/or reproject the shapefile(s) to match the projection used in the map.
  5. Follow the steps for georeferencing a raster to a vector.

Related spatial data resources

  • Spatial Data Repository
    NYU's source for spatial data. This resource also shows maps and data available to download from Harvard, Stanford, and Princeton.
  • Global Administrative Areas
    Download individual country administrative boundaries in multiple formats.
  • Natural Earth Data
    Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data, with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software.
  • Geofabrik
    Download OpenStreetMap data, including global places of interest and street networks. Updated regularly.
  • Old Maps Online
  • David Rumsey Map Collection
  • Perry-Castañeda Library Map Collection
    Unique maps from around the world available for free download, typically as a .jpg.
  • Ebook Central
    Search for "atlas" and an area of interest to find atlases with unique maps for course assignments
  • IPUMS
    IPUMS provides census and survey data, including geospatial data, from around the world integrated across time and space. IPUMS integration and documentation makes it easy to study change, conduct comparative research, merge information across data types, and analyze individuals within family and community contexts.

Geospatial Guidance

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

Using these resources

Note: The resources on this page were put together by NYU NY Data Services. For questions, comments, or concerns about the content, contact NYU NY Data Services. Visit their GIS guide for further resources and guidance.

If you are currently at NYUAD, the Geospatial Services Librarian can assist with accessing the resources.

Geospatial Analysis & File Conversion

  Geospatial Analysis & File Conversion: Understanding basic possibilities of GIS

  • GIS/Mapping Tools and Services
    Learn the definition of GIS, different GIS applications available at NYU, and GIS data sources
  • How to Get Started with ArcGIS Online
    ESRI Academy course that covers adding layers to a map, styling layers, configuring pop-ups, sharing a map as an app, and editing item details
  • How to Clip Shapefile Features to a Study Area in ArcMap
    Using the clipping tool within the ArcMap toolbox to select parts from a larger shapefile
  • How to Clip Shapefile Features to a Study Area in QGIS
    Using the clip tool within QGIS to select parts from a larger shapefile.
  • How to Create a Single Buffer around Shapefile Features in ArcMap
    Generating buffers and other areas around map features to perform analysis
  • How to Create a Single Buffer around Shapefile Features in QGIS
    Generating buffers and other areas around map features to perform analysis
  • How to Dissolve Shapefiles in ArcMap
    Aggregating or eliminating GIS layers within ArcMap
  • Introduction to ArcGIS (ArcMap)
    Become familiar with ESRI's desktop software and basic GIS concepts

Data Cleaning and Management

  Data Cleaning & Management: Transforming and manipulating data for GIS analysis

  • How to Merge Shapefiles in ArcMap
    A guide to merging shapefiles and managing GIS projects
  • How to Merge Shapefiles in QGIS
    A guide to merging shapefiles for GIS projects
  • How to Join Data in ArcMap (basic Table and Spatial Joins)
    Joining two datasets together based on a shared ID or overlapping spatial area
  • How to Join Data in QGIS (basic Table and Spatial Joins)
    Joining two datasets together based on a shared ID or overlapping spatial area
  • Open Refine
    A tool for working with messy data, cleaning it, transforming it from one format into another, extending it with web services
  • Data Cleaning Using Open Refine
    Learn an open-source tool for fast clean up of tabular data in preparation for analysis
  • DataWrangler Alpha
    A simple application to clean data and export data into text files.
  • Data Cleaning for GIS
    Develop essential strategies for cleaning data in preparation for visualization and analysis with GIS software

Geospatial Visualization

  Geospatial Visualization: Approaches to creating maps and illuminating GIS data

  • How to Get Started with ESRI StoryMaps
    ESRI Academy course that covers the basics of creating a StoryMap, adding content to it, and publishing it
  • Data Visualization with Tableau
    An introduction of basic principles of data visualization with Tableau
  • Color Brewer
    Color Brewer generates color swatches for sequential, diverging, and qualitative maps.
  • Cesium
    Cesium is a JavaScript library for creating 3D globes and 2D maps in a web browser without a plugin. It uses WebGL for hardware-accelerated graphics, and is cross-platform, cross-browser, and tuned for dynamic-data visualization. Cesium is open source under the Apache 2.0 license. It is free for commercial and non-commercial use.

Geocoding

  Geocoding: Generating latitude and longitude coordinates to reference data in GIS software

  • How to Geocode Data in ArcMap
    Establishing a geocoding tool and optimizing results in ArcMap
  • How to Geocode Data in QGIS
    Geocoding addresses in QGIS
  • Geocode by Awesome Table
    Geocode by Awesome Table is a Google Sheets add-on that allows users to derive coordinates for structured data. The add-on calls from the Google Maps API.
  • Address Geocoding with ArcGIS
    ESRI Academy course that covers the mechanics of preparing data to be geocoded within ArcMap
  • HamsterMap
    Geocode locations from decimal degree format into standard GIS format
  • Texas A&M Geocoding Services
    Texas A&M Geoservices offers geocoding that is the result of years of work. If you have a large-scale dataset, you may want to enlist this service.

Georeferencing

  Georeferencing: Ascribing location data to scanned images of historic maps

  • NYPL Map Warper
    NYPL Map Warper is a tool for digitally aligning ("rectifying") historical maps from the NYPL's collections to match today's maps. Visitors can browse already rectified maps or assist the NYPL by aligning a map.
  • David Rumsey Georeferencer
    Georeferencer from the David Rumsey collection at Stanford University is an application that allows users to overlay historic maps on modern maps or other historic maps. The overlaid maps reveal changes over time and enable map analysis and discovery.
  • Georeferencing Raster Data Using ArcGIS
    An ESRI Academy course designed to introduce the concepts and strategies of georeferencing raster images

Download workshop data

    This page includes training material available in English, French, German, Brazilian Portuguese, and Czech.

    This page provides many resources for performing common tasks in QGIS as well as other software.
  • Georeference in QGIS3 video

  • Instructions: Create custom control points
  • Instructions: Using MapWarper.net to georeference
    Having trouble georeferencing with ArcMap? Try the online tool MapWarper. Note: This only georeferences maps as Web Mercator (WGS 1984). Use the Project Raster tool in ArcMap to reproject as needed.
  • Programming Historian Lessons
    The Programming Historian has lessons in a variety of digital humanities methods, including GIS. These lessons are free, open, and peer reviewed.

Workshop resources

This workshop was led by Taylor Hixson, NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services, on 30 October 2019 for the NYUAD student chapter of the American Society of Civil Engineers. Use this guide to access resources from the workshop and as a further resource for learning about GIS in civil engineering.

  • Written guide to workshop
  • Workshop data
  • Workshop slides

Key Data Resources

  • Digital Elevation Models
    Link to digital elevation models available in the NYU Spatial Data Repository.
  • USGS Earth Explorer
  • Google Earth Engine Explorer
    Locate and download raster data from around the world. Best for when you need a small area rather than global scale. Allows basic analysis in the workspace before downloading. Create a free account for best user experience.

Key Scholarship Resources

Below are three good resources that describe geographic information systems and geospatial data in the context of civil engineering.

David  A. Holdstock. “Basis of Geographic Information Systems (GIS).” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 1, Jan. 1998, p. 4

Jack Dangermond, and Adena Schutzberg. “Engineering, Geographic Information Systems, and Databases: A New Frontier.” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 3, July 1998, p. 2.

Hassan A. Karimi. “Data Acquisition through Emerging High-Resolution Satellite Imagery.” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 3, July 1998, p. 3.

 

  • Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering: GIS Search
    Link to a search for GIS within the Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering since 1995.
  • ASCE Library
    The ASCE Library is a digital library that provides access to a collection of civil engineering content. It contains articles from ASCE journals, papers from conference proceedings, and e-books and standards.
  • Web of Science citations analysis for GIS AND "civil engineering"
    This links to a citation analysis of GIS AND "civil engineering" exported from Web of Science.

Faculty Consulting

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYUAD faculty geospatial consulting services

Services Provided

  • Prepping data for mapping or analysis (geocoding, joining data, data cleaning, reprojecting, etc.)
  • Geoprocessing
  • Conversion of geospatial data formats or extracting attribute tables
  • Geospatial data and project management
  • Creating Story Maps or ArcGIS Online web apps
  • Setting up Survey123 surveys for data collection
  • Heads-up digitizing of scanned maps
  • Creating maps for publication (acknowledgement required)
  • Creating Leaflet maps to embed on websites (website must already exist or be underdevelopment)
  • Developing training and education resources for research assistants
  • Archiving original geospatial research data in the NYU Spatial Data Repository.

It is the researcher's responsibility to ensure that the research design, analysis, and programming are justified and appropriate for the discipline at hand. Further details about the NYUAD Geospatial Services.

Services not provided

  • Debugging code
  • Software engineering or development
  • Interpretation of analysis or results
  • Database management
  • Large-scale, unsupervised machine learning
  • One-on-one GIS/mapping tutoring and general inquiries about methodology and statistical topics
  • Assistance with projects of commercial nature or those involving classified information, non-disclosure agreements, related to or likely to be involved in litigation, etc.

Community served

Current NYUAD faculty only. 

All other communities may schedule appointments and consult with the Geospatial Services Librarian about capstone assistance, finding data, choosing packages and software, interpreting errors, and other inquiries outlined on the NYU Data Services Consulting guidelines located on the NYUAD GIS Home page.

Scheduling consulting services

Faculty are required to schedule a preliminary appointment with the geospatial data services librarian to determine the approximate hours required and feasibility of the suggested work before scheduling consulting hours. Email the librarian or schedule an appointment.

The Geospatial Data Services Librarian offers 8 hours each week dedicated to working on faculty research. Those hours are not inclusive of other tasks related to instruction, finding resources, geoprocessing task run time, which a faculty member may request in addition to consulting hours. On a case-by-case basis, faculty members requiring more hours or long-term assistance may discuss research partnerships with the librarian and NYUAD Center for Digital Scholarship.
